name: Conflict Detection and Resolution
description: Tests the system's ability to detect contradictions and logical conflicts

theory.natural_language: Let me tell you about Socrates and the nature of mortality. All humans are mortal - this is a fundamental truth. Socrates is a human, therefore Socrates is mortal. Now, the Greek gods were considered immortal - they could not die. Zeus is a god, so Zeus is immortal. Here's an interesting philosophical puzzle: some ancient texts suggest that Socrates had divine wisdom, almost as if he were touched by the gods. But being mortal and being immortal are contradictory properties - nothing can be both mortal and immortal at the same time. A being is either one or the other. Also, all mortals will eventually die, while immortals live forever. Death and eternal life are mutually exclusive.

expected_answer.natural_language: No, Socrates is not immortal. Socrates is a human, humans are mortal, and mortal is the opposite of immortal.
expected_answer.explanation: Socrates IS_A human, human IS_A mortal, mortal DISJOINT_WITH immortal

queries.natural_language: Would there be a contradiction if we said Socrates is a god?

expected_answer.natural_language: Yes, there would be a contradiction. If Socrates were a god, he would be immortal (since gods are immortal). But Socrates is already established as mortal (being human). Since mortal and immortal are contradictory, claiming Socrates is a god creates a logical conflict.
expected_answer.explanation: CHECK_WOULD_CONTRADICT: Socrates IS_A mortal + god IS_A immortal + mortal DISJOINT_WITH immortal

expected_answer.natural_language: No, Zeus cannot die. Zeus is a god, gods are immortal, and immortals live forever. Death is only for mortals.
expected_answer.explanation: Zeus IS_A immortal, immortals do not die
